The War Cabinet gave further consideration to this matter,on which a Question had been put down for answer by the PrimeMinister on the following day.In discussion, all Ministers were strongly of opinion that thePrime Minister ought not to undergo the strain of making a state-ment in the House and also broadcasting on the same day. Further;,it was felt that the House would almost certainly grant this requestif the Prime Minister asked for it. Some doubts were, however,expressed as to whether a recording of a speech made in the Houseof Commons would not make it very difficult to refuse a request that other speeches should be broadcast.After discussion, the War Cabinet agreed as follows : That the Prime Minister should reply on the lines of thedraft which he read to the War Cabinet, proposing that,as an experiment, an electrical recording should be madeof the statement which he had been asked to make in thefollowing week on the present war situation. The pro-cedure contemplated was that a separate Motion would berequired on each individual recording and that the matter,should be left to a free vote of the House.Emphasis might be laid on the fact that this statement wasa very special occasion, since it was likely that the PrimeMinisters speech would be broadcast to the united nations, including, in particular, the United States andthe Dominions.Parliament. 10. W.M. (42) 9th CONCLUSIONS.19th January. 1943.PARLIAMENT. The War Cabinet were informed byProposed Visit THE FOREIGN SECRETARY that a Member of by a Member ofparliamant to Parliament wished to visit Turkey with a viewTurkey.to obtaining for his firm a contract which might otherwise be secured by the Germans.In view of the attitude taken by thisMember of Parliament, who had openly advocateda negotiated peace, it was undesirable that heshould pay a visit to Turkey, where a sectionof public opinion also favoured this view.After discussion, the War Cabinet:-(l) Invited the Foreign Secretary toinform the Member of parliament in question, privately, that itwas undesirable that he should visit Turkey:(2) Agreed that, if necessary, thereason why a permit to visit-Turkey had been refused should be stated openly.
